title-group.article-title: Influence of the Kuroshio Current intrusion on Holocene environmental transformation in the South China Sea

article-meta.aff: 1Key Laboratory of Marginal Sea Geology, South China Sea Institute of Oceanology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, China
2Key Laboratory of Marine Geology and Environment, Institute of Oceanology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, China

author-notes.corresp: Jianguo Liu, Key Laboratory of Marginal Sea Geology, South China Sea Institute of Oceanology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 164 West Xingang Road, Guangzhou 510301, China. Email: jgliu@scsio.ac.cn

abstract.p: Numerous studies have been conducted on the evolutionary history of the Kuroshio Current (KC) and other extensions. However, the history of the KC intrusion into the South China Sea (SCS) through the Luzon Strait has been little studied. Here we trace the Holocene developmental history of the KC intrusion and its impact on environmental transformation in the northern SCS. This study involved a comprehensive analysis of planktonic foraminifera, clay minerals and geochemical elements of core 05E306 sediments from the northeastern SCS. AMS 14C dates indicated that the sedimentation rate at the core site was most rapid (>1000 cm/ka) before ~6.0 ka, relatively rapid (~65 cm/ka) between 6.0 and 4.6 ka and slow (~24 cm/ka) since 4.6 ka. The Pulleniatina minimum event (PME) occurred between 4.6 and 2.7 ka, together with high percentages of Neogloboquadrina dutertrei and Globorotalia menardii. Planktonic foraminifera indicated that the KC intrusion experienced three significant changes at 6.0, 4.6 and 2.7 ka in turn. Depositional environments, including input of terrigenous materials and development of biogenic materials, similarly underwent three important transformations at 6.0, 4.1 and 3.0 ka, respectively. Abrupt changes in sedimentary records at the study core are contemporary with records from the tropical Pacific during the Holocene. This indicates that development of the KC intrusion and its impact on depositional environments in the SCS can be correlated with tropical factors from the low-latitude oceans.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The Kuroshio Current (KC) is a significant boundary current in the western Pacific Ocean, and strongly impacts regional climate in East Asia by transporting a large amount of heat from the tropics to middle latitudes (Ijiri et al., 2005). In addition, the KC affects upper-ocean thermal structure and marine sediment distributions (Diekmann et al., 2008; Jian et al., 2000). At the same time, the tropical oceans may play a major role in regulating global climate change within orbital and suborbital timescales (e.g. Koutavas et al., 2002; Visser et al., 2003). Furthermore, the strengthened KC and warm climate in the Holocene were favorable to the development and stability of agricultural societies in the Yangtze River estuary (Jian and Meng, 2002). Argos drifter buoys and satellite altimeter data indicate that the surface path of this current today conforms closely with the western boundary topography and exhibits six major turns. These turns are northward distributed at the Luzon Strait, northeast of Taiwan, around Akao, southwest of Kyushu, and south of Kyushu and Bungo Channel (Hu et al., 2008; Ma et al., 2009). Moreover, the KC correlated with sea level variations (Kao, Wu et al., 2006) migrates both seasonally and intra-seasonally, and deeply affects the flow pattern around Taiwan (Takahashi et al., 2009; Tang et al., 2000; Wu and Chiang, 2007). However, the relationship between the KC and the SCS is currently unclear, despite the fact that Kuroshio dynamics is an important component of the Southeast Asian monsoon climate system (e.g. Jian et al., 2000; Wang et al., 2000).

Shipboard acoustic Doppler current profiler (ADCP) data have shown that most of the intruded component of the KC makes a loop and flows out of the northern Luzon Strait, but a branch of the KC intrudes into the SCS (Liang et al., 2008). At the Luzon Strait, the KC intrusion into the SCS occurs in autumn and winter as a form of flow, probably related with monsoonal wind and volume transport of the KC (Kao, Roberts et al., 2006; Qin et al., 2005; Su, 2004). After entering the northern SCS, the northwestward branch of the KC further branches into western and eastern parts near 20°30′ N. The eastern part flows northward into the area southeast of Taiwan, while the western part continually intrudes northwestward into the SCS and flows through the southwest of Taiwan (Yuan et al., 2008). The current loop resulting from the KC intrusion separates near the Dongsha Islands with the northward branch (the SCS warm current) near the shelf break and the westward branch (the SCS branch of Kuroshio [SCSBK]) on the slope (Xue et al., 2004). Data of satellite-tracked drifting buoys have further revealed that most of the KC intrusion water flows west into the SCS and then turns toward the south when it reaches the east of Vietnam (Su et al., 2002). In contrast to many studies focusing on recent changes of the Kuroshio intrusion into the SCS, evaluation of the Kuroshio intrusion history during longer geological intervals has rarely been conducted in the northern SCS.

During the late Quaternary, palaeoenvironmental changes on land and neighboring sea areas of Asia were mainly dominated by the East Asian monsoon (EAM) and the KC (Yang et al., 1991). The KC variation since the last glacial has also been studied by oceanographers. Numerous sediment core studies including planktonic foraminiferal assemblages and their isotopic values have been carried out to explore the KC’s intensity and flow path, and its effect on depositional environments in the northwestern Pacific (e.g. Ijiri et al., 2005; Jian et al., 2000; Li et al., 1997; Sakamoto et al., 2005). Fluctuations of sea-surface temperature (SST) and productivity records in the northern Okinawa Trough provide evidence of KC variability during the Holocene (Huang et al., 2009). The SCSBK is an important turn of the KC at the Luzon Strait, and it can be used to explore the influence of the KC intrusion on depositional environments in the marginal seas of the western Pacific during geological timescales. However, work on the influence of the KC intrusion into the northern SCS is limited when compared with the greater number of studies focused on the KC in the Okinawa Trough and other KC branches.

The KC strongly affects hydrographic features and circulation patterns in the northern SCS. There are different opinions regarding the formation of the KC, direct branch, loop, extend and ring, which determine how the KC intrudes into the northern SCS through the Luzon Strait (Hu et al., 2000). In the northeastern SCS, sediments from the Luzon arc system and Taiwan Island are mainly transported under surface currents and north Pacific deep water (ZF Liu et al., 2008, 2010). Recent work on surface sediments further reveals that the SCSBK intensively affects depositional environments in the northern SCS. Thus the KC flow path may be traced according to the distribution of multi-proxies, including planktonic foraminifera, major and minor elements and clay minerals (JG Liu et al., 2010, 2011). Nonetheless, how SCSBK evolutionary history influenced depositional environments during the Holocene needs further investigation on core sediments from the northern SCS.

In this paper, we present a high-resolution and precisely dated sedimentary record from the northeastern SCS since the last glacial. Our study aims to: (1) characterize the temporal variation of the KC intrusion into the SCS; (2) investigate the historical transformation of depositional environments and their relationship to the KC intrusion; and (3) explore the El Niño/Southern Oscillation (ENSO) factor controlling both Kuroshio evolution and environmental transformation in the study area.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: A gravity core 05E306 (22°0.06′N, 118°59.64′E; water depth 1440 m) was collected during a cruise in 2005 by R/V Shiyan 3 of the South China Sea Institute of Oceanology (SCSIO), Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS; Figure 1). This core is 537 cm in length, and consists of greenish gray to olive gray foraminifera-bearing silty clay. In the laboratory, the core was subsampled at 2 cm intervals and measured at 4 cm intervals for major and trace elements, clay minerals and planktonic foraminiferal analyses.

caption.p: Map showing location of core 05E306 in the northern SCS and the Kuroshio Current (KC) in the western Pacific and its branches in marginal seas. The KC and its branches in the western Pacific are redrawn from Ma et al. (2009).

sec.p: Clay minerals (<2 μm) were separated according to Stoke’s settling velocity principle after removing carbonate and organic matter with 10% H2O2 and 0.5 N HCl, respectively (JG Liu et al., 2011). Clay mineralogy determinations were performed by standard x-ray diffraction (XRD) on a D8 ADVANCE diffractometer with CuKα radiation (40 kV, 25 mA) at the Key Laboratory of Marine Geology and Environment, Institute of Oceanology, Chinese Academy of Sciences (IOCAS). Identification of clay minerals was made mainly using the position of the (001) series of basal reflections on the XRD diagram of ethylene glycol salvation. Relative percentages of the four main clay mineral groups were estimated by weighting integrated peak areas of characteristic basal reflections (smectite-17Å, illite-10Å, and kaolinite/chlorite-7Å) in the glycolated state using the Topas 2P software with empirical factors from Biscaye (1965). Relative proportions of kaolinite and chlorite were determined using the ratio of the 3.57/3.54Å peak areas.

Bulk sediment samples from core 05E306 in the SCS were oven dried at 60°C and then ground to less than 63 μm using an agate pestle and mortar. After being dissolved with a HF+HNO3 acid mixture, major and trace elements were analyzed with inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS), respectively. Results from the analysis were consistent with reference values. The differences for most elements were less than 5%. Both ICP-AES and ICP-MS measurements were carried out at the IOCAS.

Samples were oven dried at 60°C, then soaked in distilled water for about 24h to disaggregate, wet-sieved through a 63 μm sieve, and then dried again in an oven. To trace the KC intrusion route, six planktonic foraminiferal species (Globigerinoides ruber, G. sacculifer, Neogloboquadrina dutertrei, Pulleniatina obliquiloculata, Globorotalia menardii and Orbulina universa) were identified and counted in the coarse fraction (>63 μm). In this paper, their relative abundance was computed based on the 63–250 μm data set.

Planktonic foraminifera from eight horizons in core 05E306 were picked for AMS 14C dating at the Xi’an Accelerator Mass Spectrometry Center, China, and more than 20 mg of tests were picked from the >150 μm fraction for further measurements. All the following ages are reported as calendar years before present (ka BP, Table 1).

caption.p: AMS 14C ages and calendar ages for core 05E306 from the northern South China Sea.

fn.p: Notes: △ indicates data point not adopted in the age-model reconstruction; *AMS 14C ages are transferred using the software Calib6.11 (Reimer et al., 2009).

sec.title: Age model and sedimentation rate
sec.p: Among the eight AMS 14C dates on planktonic foraminifera, six dates were chosen to generate a detailed timescale for core 05E306 (Table 1 and Figure 2). The other two dates show abnormally older ages than those from below, presumably caused by bioturbation. Moreover, the Pulleniatina minimum event (PME) at the depth of 60–98 cm occurred widely in the KC drainage areas between 4.6 ka and 2.7 ka (e.g. Jian et al., 1996, 2000; Li et al., 1997; Ujiie et al., 2003). Thus the start and end times of this event were also chosen to better constrain an age model for the study area.

caption.p: Calibrated calendar ages of mixed planktonic foraminifera and sedimentation rates at core 05E306 from the northern SCS. The AMS 14C ages had been converted into calibrated calendar years according to Reimer et al. (2009) using CALIB6.11. The beginning and end of the Pulleniatina minimum event (PME) are adopted from Lin et al. (2006) and Ijiri et al. (2005), while two other ages at layers of 332–334 cm and 494–496 cm are not adopted in the age-model reconstruction due to conversed ages or an abnormally high sedimentation rate between the neighboring points.

sec.p: Based on this age model, the sedimentation rate of core 05E306 shows three major periods: a very high sedimentation rate of 1052 cm/ka between 7.60 ka and 7.35 ka; a moderate sedimentation rate of 64.8 cm/ka between 7.35 and 4.60 ka; and a low sedimentation rate of 24.4 cm/ka between 4.60 and 0.75 ka (Figure 2). Sample resolution during the periods of 7.6–7.35 ka, 7.35–4.60 ka and 4.60–0.75 ka are ~4 a, 62 a, and 164 a, respectively. Conversely, a study northeast of Taiwan revealed that the KC main flow reenters the Okinawa Trough, which results in an abrupt increase in sedimentation rate at that site at about 7.3 ka (Jian et al., 2000). This probably indicates that the KC not only accelerated sedimentation rate in the northeast of Taiwan, but also slowed sedimentation rate in the southwest of Taiwan at that time.

sec.title: Planktonic foraminiferal records
sec.p: The planktonic foraminiferal fauna in core 05E306 sediments is dominated by six tropical to subtropical species, including P. obliquiloculata (average 21.8% for 135 samples), N. dutertrei (average 18.9%), G. sacculifer (average 12.1%), G. ruber (average 11.6%), G. menardii (average 5.2%) and O. universa (average 1.7%), which together constitute 71.4% of the total assemblage. Lin and Hsieh (2007) also concluded that six dominant species of planktonic foraminifera constituted 60–98% of all foraminiferal tests in the suite of samples collected through analysis of foraminiferal census data in seawater collected by plankton tows in the SCS.

Over the past 7.6 ka, planktonic foraminiferal assemblages clearly changed three times, at 4.6 ka, 3.3 ka and 1.7 ka, respectively. At the depth of 60–98 cm (corresponding to the PME; Figure 3), the percentage of P. obliquiloculata is the lowest (average <1% for 10 samples), while that of G. menardii is the highest (average 10%).

caption.p: Downcore variations in relative abundance of six common planktonic foraminiferal species in core 05E306 from the northern SCS. Shaded area indicates the PME. Red dashed lines represent division of planktonic foraminifera over the past 7.6 ka.

sec.p: During zone I (7.6–4.6 ka), the percentages of both G. ruber and G. menardii are low, while the percentages of both G. sacculifer and P. obliquiloculate are high. At 4.6 ka, the percentages of P. obliquiloculata and G. sacculifer decrease sharply from 13.0% and 20.3% to just 0.6% and 14.2%, respectively. By contrast, the percentage of G. menardii increases 3.7% to 12.6% at the same time. During zone II (4.6–3.3 ka), the percentage of P. obliquiloculata shows an average of only 0.5%, while the average percentage of G. menardii can reach 8.8%. During zone III (3.3–1.7 ka), the percentage of P. obliquiloculata increases gradually until 18% at around 1.7 ka, while the percentage of N. dutertrei decreases from 25.4% at ~3.3 ka to 5.1% at ~1.7 ka. Percentages of both N. dutertrei and G. menardii during zone IV (since 1.7 ka) are the lowest in average, while the percentage of P. obliquiloculata remains relatively high (average 15.0%).

sec.title: Clay mineral records
sec.p: In the northern SCS, sediments from Taiwan are characterized by high percentages of illite and chlorite, while sediments from the Pearl River and Luzon are characterized by high percentages of kaolinite and smectite, respectively (JG Liu et al., 2011; ZF Liu et al., 2008, 2010; Wan et al., 2008). At core 05E306, clay minerals in core sediments contain illite (76–90%, average 84% for 135 samples), chlorite (3–16%, average 11%), kaolinite (1–9%, average 3%) and smectite (1–5%, average 2%).

During the last 7.6 ka, clay mineral percentages reveal two significant large-scale changes at the study core. These occur at 6.1 ka and 4.1 ka, respectively (Figure 4). Thus their fluctuation can be divided into three zones.

caption.p: Downcore variations in relative abundance of clay minerals in core 05E306 from the northern SCS. Shaded area indicates the PME. Red dashed lines represent division of clay minerals over the past 7.6 ka.

sec.p: Zone I (7.6–6.1 ka): illite percentage at this zone is the highest, with an average of 84% for 84 samples, while the percentage of chlorite is the lowest with an average of 10%.

Zone II (6.1–4.1 ka): illite percentage at 6.1 ka decreases sharply from 90.2% to 81.3%, while the chlorite percentage increases from 6.7% to 12.2%. During this period, average illite percentage is the lowest, but the percentage of chlorite reaches the highest among 31 samples.
Zone III (since 4.1 ka): over the past 4.1 ka, the illite percentage fluctuates between 78% and 86% with an average of 83% for 19 samples.

sec.title: Principal component analysis
sec.p: To extract the common variables of different proxies, principal component analysis (PCA) was conducted on 35 geochemical elements (here 14 rare earth elements are classified as REE due to their similar distribution patterns) of surface sediments using Statistical Package for the Social Sciences (SPSS) software. These elements are grouped into four assemblages, which explain 69.1% of the total variance (Table 2).

caption.p: Variance of major and trace elements during different zones at core 05E306 from the northern SCS and results of principal component analyses for them.

fn.p: Notes: Unit for Al2O3, CaO, Fe2O3, K2O, MgO, MnO, Na2O, P2O5 and TiO2 concentrations are percent, while others are ppm; *three abnormally high Pb values are not calculated here. Bold numbers correspond to elements with relatively high loadings in each principal component.

sec.p: Factor 1 (PC1) explains 28.7% of the total variance, which is dominated by MnO, Sc, V, Cr, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Ga, Rb, Nb, Ba and REE. Enriched as oxyhydroxides at intermediate water depths in the SCS (Calvert et al., 1993), Mn concentration is controlled by the penetration depth of dissolved oxygen from the overlying water column and organic matter flux to the sediments (Rozanov et al., 2006). Ba in marine sediments is concentrated by marine organisms and correlated with marine productivity (Schnetger et al., 2000). Thus this factor is mostly related to marine productivity and redox conditions, which agrees with previous study results on surface sediments in the northern SCS (JG Liu et al., 2011).

Factor 2 (PC2) has high loadings of Al2O3, Fe2O3, K2O, TiO2, Cs, Ta, W and Th, which explain 22.5% of the variance. Because of low concentration in seawater, Ti in the form of suspended clastics (Zhao et al., 2002) is taken as the best proxy to denote terrestrial input to the SCS sediments (JG Liu et al., 2011; Wei et al., 2003). In addition, Al2O3 and Fe2O3 distributions may be affected by redox processes and pyritization (Sirocko et al., 2000). Due to authigenic processes, a non-detrital Al component appears in the bulk sediments from the SCS (Wei et al., 2003). Therefore this factor mainly reflects terrigenous input and authigenic process in the study area.

Factor 3 (PC3) has high loadings of Y, Zr, Hf and U, which explain 10.9% of the total variance. In the SCS, distribution of Y is largely controlled by the presence of phosphorite (Calvert et al., 1993). In sediments from the China Shelf Sea, both Zr and Hf are enriched in heavy minerals (especially zircon), while areas with high U concentrations also agree with high Zr and Hf concentrations (Zhao et al., 2002). This relationship is confirmed by the high correlation between these concentrations (r>0.65). Hence this factor is correlated with the presence of terrigenous materials, especially heavy minerals.

Factor 4 (PC4) accounts for 7.0% of the total variance, and has high loadings of CaO, MgO, Na2O and Sr. In surface sediments from the northern SCS, CaO and Sr are related to biogenic carbonate, while MgO and Na2O are connected with seawater exchange, probably due to intrusion of the KC and/or North Pacific deep water (NPDW; JG Liu et al., 2011). At core 05E306, the high correlation between CaO and Sr (r = 0.78) confirms that both constituents are likely to be correlated with biogenic activities. Consequently, this factor is considered to be mainly correlated with biogenic processes and seawater exchange in the study area.

sec.title: Vertical variability of the geochemical compositions
sec.p: During the last 7.6 ka, the geochemical composition of core 05E306 experienced three important changes, at about 6.0, 4.6, and ~3.0 ka (Figure 5). Their fluctuation can be divided into four zones: Zone I (7.6–6.0 ka); Zone II (6.0–4.6 ka); Zone III (4.6–3.0 ka); and Zone IV (since 3.0 ka).

caption.p: Downcore variations of four principal components and typical elements among them in core 05E306 from the northern SCS. Shaded area indicates the PME. Red dashed lines represent division of geochemical elements over the past 7.6 ka.

sec.p: Zone I (7.6–6.0 ka): at about 6.0 ka, some parameters, including PC3, U, CaO and Sr, began to increase, while other parameters, including PC1, REE, PC2, Al2O3, Fe2O3 and TiO2, began to decrease.

Zone II (6.0–4.6 ka): although most elemental concentrations still changed dramatically, Fe2O3 concentration in this zone remained relatively stable compared with the former one (Table 2). TiO2 concentration in this zone also fluctuated less than that in the former one, except for a general decrease.
Zone III (4.6–3.0 ka): at 4.6 ka, many elemental concentrations, including Al2O3, TiO2, Y, Zr, U, CaO and Sr, increased abruptly.

Zone IV (since 3.0 ka): at about 3.0 ka, many elemental concentrations clearly changed. Concentrations of biogenic related elements (e.g. Ba, CaO and Sr), terrigenous denoted elements (e.g. Al2O3, Fe2O3, TiO2), seawater exchange correlated elements (e.g. MgO) and redox associated elements (e.g. MnO) changed sharply at this time.

sec.title: Evolutionary history of the KC intrusion in the northern SCS
sec.p: Planktonic foraminifera, including G. ruber and G. sacculifer as surface seawater dwellers (living at 0–25 m depth) and N. dutertrei and P. obliquiloculata as subsurface seawater dwellers (living at 25–100 m depth), have been successfully utilized to trace the KC flow route in the western Pacific, including the Okinawa Trough (OT) and the SCS (e.g. Lin and Hsieh, 2007; Mohiuddin et al., 2004; Ujiie et al., 2003). G. sacculifer and N. dutertrei are distributed on the KC intrusion route in the northern SCS, while G. ruber and P. obliquiloculata are distributed on the shallow and deep edge of the SCSKC flow route, respectively (JG Liu et al., 2011). Furthermore, O. universa and G. menardii occurred in low latitudes (Kawahata et al., 2002) and are abundant in warm and less-mixed surface ocean conditions in the SCS (Chen et al., 1998).

During the Holocene, sea level in the western Pacific marginal seas started to ascend from about 35 m below present levels at ~10 ka, to the highest sea level (1–2 m higher than the present) at 7–6 ka (JP Liu et al., 2002, 2007; Tanabe et al., 2003). In that interval, the flux and influence of KC water on the northern SCS weakened greatly, which might be explained by the entrance of surface water from the Indian Ocean and Java Sea through the Karimata Strait in summer, and southward flow of cold water through the Taiwan Strait in winter (Wang et al., 1994).

In the northeastern SCS, the lowest percentages of G. ruber and G. menardii at core 05E306, together with the highest percentage of P. obliquiloculata between 7.6 ka and 4.6 ka, indicate that the impact of the KC on the study area was strong, and the axis of SCSBK probably shifted northward at that time. In the northern OT, the impact of the KC strengthened rapidly during 7.3–4.6 ka, with surface seawater warming and terrigenous materials diminishing there (Huang et al., 2009). In the southern OT, the P. obliquiloculata maximum zone occurred at around 7–6 ka, and corresponded to the mid-Holocene climate optimum (Li et al., 1997; Shi et al., 1993). At the same time, the KC reached its strongest point during the period of 7–6 ka, and ultimately resulted in formation of the warm current system in the East China Sea (ECS) and Yellow Sea at about 6.4 ka (Dou et al., 2010a; Li et al., 2009; Xiang et al., 2007).

On the SCSBK flow route, the PME occurred between 4.6 and 2.7 ka BP, and coincided with high G. menardii and N. dutertrei occurrences at core 05E306. This pattern also indicates that the KC’s intensity changed less than the former period, but warm planktonic foraminifera (G. menardii) arrived in the study area. A significant change in Kuroshio water was the appearance of the PME throughout KC drainage areas (e.g. Jian et al., 1996, 2000; Lin et al., 2006; Ujiie et al., 2003). In the Ryukyu Arc area (the KC source region), no clear cooling signal was identified during the PME from ~4.5 ka to 3.0 ka, except for the severe reduction and disappearance of the Pulleniatina group and the high abundance of N. dutertrei. Thus this event has been interpreted as marking the beginning of the typical ENSO system in the Equatorial Pacific Ocean (Ujiie et al., 2003). At the KC mainstream and edge of the modern Tsushima Warm Current, this event occurred at 5.3–2.8 ka. This event was characterized by decreasing abundances of P. obliquiloculata and G. glutinata, increasing percentages of G. inflata and N. dutertrei, and excursion in δ18O and δ13C of G. ruber and N. dutertrei, suggesting that dramatic changes occurred in SST and nutrient concentration during that time (Li et al., 2009). Records in the northern OT revealed that SST was reduced by 0.8–1.4°C and the KC intensity weakened or its main axis shifted towards the Pacific Ocean (Huang et al., 2009). However, Mg/Ca and δ18O measurements on G. ruber shells from the southern OT indicate that there was no change in SST or sea surface salinity (SSS) during the PME of ~4.5–3.0 ka (Lin et al., 2006). Similarly in the ECS, SST from alkenones (U37K’) did not change during the PME from 4.5 ka to 3.0 ka (Ijiri et al., 2005). At the same time, Li et al. (1997) attributed the PME to a decrease in winter SST caused by an intensified winter monsoon. Jian et al. (2000) also interpreted that this event of sharp decreasing P. obliquiloculata abundance was likely related to a weakened KC at that time and strengthened coastal currents due to intensified winter monsoons. Recently, Li et al. (2009) confirmed that this event was accompanied by a small δ18O decrease of G. ruber and was probably caused by weakening of the KC’s intensity rather than by a track shift.

During the period of 3.3–1.7 ka, P. obliquiloculata percentages at core 05E306 continually increased, together with high G. menardii percentages, indicating that the KC strengthened rapidly and more warm species of planktonic foraminifera (e.g. G. menardii) flourished in the northern SCS. In the Tsushima warm current and the KC-dominated area, planktonic foraminiferal fauna and isotope records show a short-term wiggle of the current at ~3 ka, probably due to the EAWM enhancement and the KC depression (Li et al., 2007).

Over the last 1.7 ka, G. ruber and G. sacculifer percentages at core 05E306 reached their maxima while N. dutertrei and G. menardii percentages were at their lowest. This trend indicated that the KC weakened and less warm species of planktonic foraminifera were flourishing there. Under the KC’s influence in the northern Okinawa Trough, marine productivity has increased and upwelling has developed since 2.7 ka (Huang et al., 2009). In the central Okinawa Trough, sedimentary records indicate that the KC has probably weakened since 1.5 ka, with a result of an abrupt increase in the proportion of Yangtze River-sourced clays (Dou et al., 2010b). In the southern Okinawa Trough, the KC’s strength intensified step by step after 3.0 ka (Jiang, 2007). In other words, during the late Holocene, the KC has normally been considered to be weakened or shifted towards the Pacific side (Jian et al., 2000; Ujiie and Ujiie, 1999).

sec.title: Transformation of depositional environments in the northern SCS
sec.p: Presently, the KC migrates both seasonally and intraseasonally (Takahashi et al., 2009; Tang et al., 2000; Wu and Chiang, 2007), which inevitably changes depositional environments on its flow route. In the OT, sedimentary records have already revealed this impact based on multiproxies, including geochemical composition, clay mineral assemblages and grain size distribution (e.g. Diekmann et al., 2008; Dou et al., 2010a, 2010b). Similarly, at core 05E306 from the northeastern SCS, transformation of depositional environments is also correlated with the KC intrusion.

As sediments from Taiwan are characterized by high illite percentages, increasing illite percentages before 6.0 ka BP at core 05E306 indicate that increasing Taiwan-sourced sediments were transported and then deposited in the study area at that time. In the southern OT, river sediments from northeastern Taiwan dominate, due to strong ocean circulation under direct and persistent effects of the KC (Diekmann et al., 2008). In the central OT, Taiwan-sourced clays have dominated the sediment flux (around 20%) since 8.4 ka, which coincided with the re-entrance of the KC into the trough (Dou et al., 2010b). Sediment provenance analysis has further revealed that the KC main stream strengthened since about 7 ka, resulting in Taiwan-sourced terrigenous sediments dominating in the middle trough (Dou et al., 2010a).

In the northeastern SCS, the influence of Taiwan-sourced sediments denoted by the percentage of illite strengthens continuously between 6.0 ka and 4.6 ka. However, terrestrial material inputs denoted by TiO2 and Al2O3 concentrations decreases step by step within the study core. The northern OT was abruptly affected by the KC during 7.3–4.6 ka, with the resulting decrease of terrigenous matter inputs (Huang et al., 2009). During this period of about 6.4–4.0 ka, when the KC was one of the dominant factors on the Yellow Sea warm current (YSWC) evolution, the cold water body of benthic foraminifera, related to the YSWC, was extremely active in the Yellow Sea, and led to the quick formation of the southeastern Yellow Sea muddy deposit area (Li et al., 2009).

The PME occurred widely in the western Pacific between 4.6 ka and 3.0 ka. Taiwan sediments input generally decreased, except for at ~4.1 ka, when the illite percentages sharply increased, and the illite chemistry index and REE concentration abruptly decreased (Figures 4–5). At the same time, the KC’s intensity weakened or its main axis shifted towards the Pacific Ocean, resulting in a strengthened impact of the diluted water from the continental shelf, and a great increase of terrigenous material input into the northern OT (Huang et al., 2009; Jian et al., 2000). On the ECS shelf, the summer monsoon and corresponding KC were markedly enhanced between 8.0 ka and 4.1 ka (particularly during the 4.6–4.1 ka period), but the winter monsoon and Zhejiang-Fujian coastal current prevailed during the 4.1–0.7 ka period (Zhang et al., 2010).

Since 3.0 ka, terrigenous material inputs indicated by TiO2, REE and Ba increased more than before, while authigenic processes, synchronously indicated by Al2O3, Fe2O3 and MnO, strengthened clearly in the northeastern SCS. In addition, biogenic activity in the study core, indicated by CaO and Sr, developed greatly during this period. All these results suggest that the KC strengthened and more terrigenous materials are transported into the study area. In the middle OT, clay mineral assemblages suggest that the increasing influence of the Yangtze River-sourced sediments since 1.5 ka was similarly connected with the KC’s weakening and/or a higher river flux (Dou et al., 2010b).

sec.title: ENSO factor controlling both the KC evolution and environmental transformation in the northern SCS
sec.p: At core 05E306 from the northeastern SCS, sedimentary records revealed four important changes: at ~6.0, 4.6, 3.3 and 1.7 ka in turn. These are contemporary with the ENSO records from the tropical Pacific (Figure 6).

caption.p: Comparison of: (a) ENSO amplitude; (b) number of ENSO events (Clement et al., 2000); (c) TiO2; (d) illite; and (e) P. obliquiloculata in core 05E306 from the northern SCS.

sec.p: At ~6.0 ka, P. obliquiloculata percentages reached their maxima, while illite percentages decreased greatly in the study area, where large amounts of terrigenous materials were discharged (Figure 6). At that time, ENSO amplitude increased gradually, but the number of ENSO events decreased in the tropical Pacific (Clement et al., 2000). Before 6.0 ka, Taiwan-sourced sediments had a major impact at core 05E306 (ZF Liu et al., 2008, 2010).

At about 4.6 ka, the input of Taiwan-sourced sediments decreased at core 05E306 from the northeastern SCS, where P. obliquiloculata percentage decreased rapidly at ~4.6 ka until the occurrence of the PME between 4.6 ka and ~3.0 ka. Almost simultaneously, the ENSO amplitude and number of ENSO events started to increase continuously in the tropical Pacific, where the marine and terrestrial palaeoclimatic proxy data consistently indicate that a status change occurred at ~5 ka toward active ENSO cyclicity (Donders et al., 2008).

At ~3.3 ka, the ENSO amplitude was relatively low, but the number of ENSO events was high in the tropical Pacific. Since then, P. obliquiloculata percentages began to increase gradually at core 05E306, and the input of terrigenous materials increased continually in the study area. By contrast, Mg/Ca temperature of G. ruber decreased continually in the Indo-Pacific warm pool (IPWP). The marine and terrestrial palaeoclimatic proxy data also indicate that the ENSO-teleconnected regions are characterized by an increased impact of ENSO from around 3 ka (Donders et al., 2008).

At ~1.7 ka, the number of ENSO events increased continuously until a peak was reached at around 1.6 ka, when ENSO amplitude was relatively stable in the tropical Pacific. Within the study core, P. obliquiloculata percentages remained relatively high, while inputs of terrigenous materials were low together with weak impact of Taiwan-sourced sediments.

In fact, the tropical oceans, especially the tropical western Pacific, may play a major role in regulating climate change (e.g. Stott et al., 2002; Visser et al., 2003) through their effects on global distribution of heat and water vapor (Abram et al., 2009), known as the ENSO cycle (Trenberth et al., 1998). Since the KC is sourced from northward branches of the North Equatorial Current, these may carry a large amount of heat from low latitude warm pool to middle latitude KC extensions. Ujiie et al. (2003) have suggested that the PME was a possible proxy signal of El Niño-like conditions and enhancement of the ENSO climate system. Thus the ENSO will have inevitably left marks in the KC drainage areas (e.g. Chen and Liu, 2010; Chiang et al., 2010; Wang et al., 2000), including the study core site from the northeastern SCS.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Sedimentary records on core 05E306 are used to trace Holocene evolution of the KC intrusion and its impact on depositional environments in the northeastern SCS. Planktonic foraminifera may be connected to the KC intrusion, while clay minerals and elemental records also respond to the KC intrusion into the study area.

Sedimentation rates at core 05E306 were divided into three periods: very fast (>1000 cm/ka; between 7.6 and 6.0 ka), relatively fast (~65 cm/ka; between 6.0 and 4.6 ka), and slow (~24 cm/ka; since 4.6 ka).

High percentages of P. obliquiloculata coincided with low percentages of G. ruber, N. dutertrei and G. menardii before 4.6 ka. The PME normally existed in the KC drainage areas, and also appeared within the study core, together with high percentages of N. dutertrei and G. menardii between 4.6 and 2.7 ka. Since 2.7 ka P. obliquiloculata percentages gradually increased while G. menardii percentages continually decreased.

Clay minerals at core 05E306 were also divided into four clear zones, separated at 7.1, 6.0 and 4.1 ka. Illite percentage between 7.1 and 6.0 ka reached a peak, while the average chlorite percentage between 6.0 and 4.1 ka was at its highest. Terrigenous material inputs, indicated by Al2O3, Fe2O3 and TiO2, were the highest before 6.0 ka, relatively high since 3.0 ka, relatively low between 6.0 and 4.6 ka and low between 4.6 and 3.0 ka. Biogenic activity, indicated by CaO and Sr, mostly developed since 3.0 ka.

Abrupt changes shown in sedimentary records at core 05E306 from the northeastern SCS were contemporaneous with the ENSO records from the tropical Pacific. These records indicate that Holocene evolution of the KC intrusion and its impact on depositional environments in the northern SCS are likely correlated with tropical factors from the low-latitude oceans at that time.

ack.p: We thank the South China Sea Open Cruise by R/V Shiyan 3, South China Sea Institute of Oceanology, CAS, and investigations of Nansha Island and the adjacent sea for sampling. Thanks are also expressed to Dr. Zhimin Jian for his constructive advice. The authors would also like to thank two anonymous reviewers for their comments, which significantly helped to improve this manuscript. We are also grateful to Yang Chen for improving the English text.
